questions.question: Why would a network administrator choose OSPF over RIP for routing within a large enterprise network?
options: OSPF has simpler configuration requirements
OSPF uses hop count as its metric which is more accurate
OSPF converges faster and supports larger networks without routing loops
OSPF automatically balances traffic across all available paths
questions.explanation: OSPF uses link-state routing with Dijkstra's algorithm, enabling faster convergence and loop-free routing in large networks, unlike RIP's distance-vector approach which has convergence issues and hop count limitations.

questions.question: In an OSPF network, what is the primary purpose of dividing the autonomous system into areas?
options: To enable different routing protocols in each area
To reduce routing table size and limit LSA flooding scope
To automatically load balance traffic between areas
To prevent any communication between different network segments
questions.explanation: OSPF areas create hierarchical routing that reduces routing table sizes and limits Link State Advertisement (LSA) flooding to specific areas, improving scalability and reducing processing overhead.

questions.question: A network has multiple equal-cost paths between two destinations. How does OSPF handle this scenario by default?
options: Uses only the first path discovered
Alternates between paths for each packet
Performs load balancing across all equal-cost paths
Randomly selects one path and uses it exclusively
questions.explanation: OSPF supports Equal Cost Multi-Path (ECMP) routing by default, automatically distributing traffic across all paths with the same lowest cost to improve bandwidth utilization and provide redundancy.

questions.question: When would an OSPF Designated Router (DR) election occur on a network segment?
options: Only when manually configured by an administrator
On point-to-point links to reduce overhead
On multi-access networks like Ethernet to minimize LSA exchanges
When connecting different OSPF areas together
questions.explanation: DR election happens on multi-access networks (like Ethernet) to reduce the number of adjacencies and LSA exchanges. On a network with n routers, DR/BDR reduces adjacencies from n(n-1)/2 to 2(n-1).

questions.question: A company's OSPF network is experiencing slow convergence after link failures. What is the most likely cause and solution?
options: Too many areas configured; consolidate into a single area
Insufficient bandwidth; upgrade all links to higher capacity
Large single area with many routers; implement proper area hierarchy
Incorrect router IDs; manually assign sequential numbers
questions.explanation: A large flat OSPF area causes slow convergence because every router must recalculate the entire topology. Implementing hierarchical areas (connecting via Area 0) localizes topology changes and speeds convergence.
